content:
Decided to consolidate my portfolio a bit by exiting $REVB for effectively breakeven (1.10-1.11 exit average) and buying more $NVIV 1.28-1.32 range. 
 
Holdings: 
~2.0%-2.5% $AEZS 
~0.5% $ARTL 
~0.5% $NVIV 
<0.5% $PULM

Bought more $REVB ~1.08-1.09. 
 
Current holdings: 
~2.0%-2.5% $AEZS 
~0.5%-1.0% $REVB 
<0.5% $ARTL 
<0.5% $NVIV 
<0.5% $PULM

(3/3) 
Own: $AEZS $PULM $NVIV $REVB $ARTL 
Watchlist: $ASLN $LUMO $NERV $RKDA $MDGS $VYNE $ENVB $CWBR $APRE $HSTO $PHIO $DRMA $PALI $RSLS $NUWE $SILO $SNOA $SINT $SNES $SPRC $SLRX $PTIX $NXGL $THMO

(2/3) Buy: 
$NVIV – Got a very small position ~$1.14, but name started running before I could get more. 
$REVB – Got a very small position ~$1.08-$1.09, but name started running before I could get more.

(1/3) Sell/Trim: 
$SPRC – Felt I should just book the small 5%-10% loss at ~$0.70 and move on, so am out. 
$ARTL – Trimmed small portion of position at ~$2.70 and ~$2.86 last week. Continue to own.

(3/3) In terms of the watchlist, it remains at an all-time high in terms of # of names. See below: 
 
Own $AEZS $SPRC $ARTL $PULM 
Watchlist $DFFN $NXGL $BRTX $HSTO $CWBR $LUMO $ENVB $CNSP $NUWE $PALI $SILO $BVXV $PHIO $APM $SLRX $SINT $REVB $RSLS $PTPI $MDGS

(2/3) As far as reinvesting the proceeds, decided to buy a ~1% position in $SPRC at $0.77. At a $2.8 million market cap, I like the upside. It’s been a choppy quarter so far. Up 6% vs. a 1% increase for $XBI. Just trying to limit risk and hang in there.

(1/3) Portfolio update. Decided to exit $CYTO today. Looks like additional shares coming for loan payback. I sat through decline of >50% in CYTO, all to exit for a loss of ~7%-8%. That’s an okay result for taking a big gamble. Entry average of $4.93 and exit average $4.56.

(3/3) My watchlist has thinned out. I had >20 names on it, but now down to 14 names. More than normal, but off all-time highs. 
 
I Own: 
~2.5% $AEZS 
~0.5% $PULM 
~0.5% $ARTL 
~0.5% $CYTO 
 
Watchlist:  $LUMO $NRBO $CWBR $HSTO $DFFN $ENVB $NUWE $CNSP $PALI $BRTX $SILO $SNOA $FRTX $NXGL
(2/3) $CYTO Will aim to tweet in greater detail on it when I have a bit more time. @RealWillTopol on Twitter put the name on my radar about a month ago and have been tracking it since.

(1/3) Portfolio update. Trimmed off some $ARTL at $3.37 average for 30% gain. This trim to was to fund new position in $CYTO at $4.93 average. Not a huge position and taking a little bit of a calculated risk here, but like the risk/reward.

(6/6) $XBI One trend to watch out for is companies moving to wind down / liquidation. We already had $NBRV $OTIC $SIOX and now we have $CALA. There will be more. Public markets investors need to be careful with companies lacking cash runway.
(5/6) $XBI More than 250 companies are burring more cash than their respective market caps!
(4/6) $XBI Even though there was a small rally for some negative EV companies after tax-loss selling, the number of negative EV companies remains around an all-time high.

(3/6) $XBI $IBB Interest rates tend to move inversely with biotech. Particularly with biotech valuations driven by the present value of future cash flows, this makes sense. Declines in interest rates would be bullish for biotech.
(2/6) $XBI has been flat over the past 5 years.
(6/5) Here's the overview of my holdings ( $AEZS $ARTL $PULM ) and watchlist:

(5/5) Microcap bios have enormous potential. I’m going to use these criteria as I make selections. 
 
I’m enthusiastic about my current holdings: $AEZS $ARTL $PULM 
 
On the watchlist: $LUMO $NRBO $NBRV $CWBR $DFFN $HSTO $ENVB $NUWE $BRTX $CNSP $FRTX $SNOA $PTPI $HILS $NXGL

(2/5) In Q4, $ENVB was a poor investment. While it wasn’t a huge dollar value in the investment, a return of around -50% on the investment (exited $3.02 per share) on the investment hurt. Selling was a smart move as $ENVB declined another 30% while buying $ARTL is up 12%.
(1/5) Completed the year with a -13% performance this year versus -26% for the $XBI. Had a fair amount of outperformance in the first 3 quarters but gave up about 20 points of outperformance in Q4.

$AEZS trading at 1/3rd current net cash value (-$30 million enterprise value) continues to surprise me. In the pipeline, AEZS is pursuing 7 indications across 4 programs. AEZS additional already has Macrilen approved in AGHD. Newsflow will pick up and be active - just a matter of when.

(4/4) My holdings: 
$AEZS ~2.0%-2.5% 
$ARTL ~0.5%-1.0% 
$PULM ~0.5% 
 
Watchlist: 
$LUMO $NRBO $NBRV $CWBR $ENVB $DFFN $HSTO $NUWE $CNSP $BRTX $BPTH $SLNO $FRTX $HOTH $SNOA $SILO $PTPI $NXGL

(3/4) The size of my watchlist continues to be at an all-time high. There is a ton of opportunity in microcap bios. 
 
As mentioned, I increased my $AEZS stake from 2.0% to 2.5%.
Increased my $AEZS stake from 2.0% to 2.5% with buys  at 3.20. One of the cheapest microchips out there and continue to see a lot of upside.
$ABIO Seven months since Ladenburg Thalmann was brought on 7 months ago. Surprised it is taking so long to get something done. Wishing the best for patient holders.
$ARTL Thanks for the summary, @PatienceisGrace

(4/4) 
Own: 
~2% $AEZS 
~0.5% $PULM 
~0.5%-1.0% $ARTL 
 
Watchlist:   
$LUMO $NBRV $CWBR $NRBO $HSTO $DFFN $ENVB $FRTX $BPTH $BRTX $HOTH $SLNO $NXGL $SNOA $HILS

(3/4) $XBI Amount of opportunity out there continues to be around an all-time high in microcaps. I’m breakeven for the year (which I am happy with considering the market) and also breakeven for this quarter (which is lagging a bit). Excited about prospects for next few months.

(2/4) Like both, but feel $ARTL has a good mix of long cash runway, later-stage assets (versus $ENVB), upcoming catalysts, etc. $ARTL was a very good investment for me back in 2019 and in 2020 so will be looking to repeat that here.
(1/4) Decided to make a portfolio tweak. Continue to like $ENVB, but there’s a lot of opportunity out there in terms of alternatives. As such, decided to sell $ENVB for a loss and buy $ARTL.

(2/2) Interestingly, most of them actually have good cash runways and can wait at least 1-2 quarters to raise. I continue to stay invested. 
 
Own: $AEZS $PULM $ENVB 
Watchlist: $NRBO $ARTL $DFFN $CWBR $FRTX $BRTX $APVO $SLNO $HSTO $HOTH $ERNA $NXGL $SILO $HILS $SNOA

(1/2) $XBI has been flat this quarter and my portfolio has been right in line with that. 
 
Volume of names trading below book/cash in microcap bios continues to be more than I've ever seen in the past 10 years.

Even though $XBI is ~30% higher than May'22/Jun'22 lows, there is a ton of opportunity in the microcap space: 
 
I Own:  $AEZS $PULM $NVB 
Watchlist:  $DFFN $INDP $ARTL $FRTX $BRTX $SLNO $APVO $HSTO $HOTH $GRI $NXGL $SILO $HILS

(4/4) – Lot of opportunity out there right now. 
 
Own:  $AEZS $PULM $ENVB 
Watchlist:  $DFFN $ARTL $INDP $APVO $GRI $NXGL $SNOA
(3/4) – Basically, everything except $CYCC and $ABIO provided a realized gain (includes $DRMA $LABU $APVO $NXGL ).
(2/4) – Seemed to be a better quarter than Q2’22 in terms of opportunities to be a stock picker. My Q3’22 results were not as correlated with the $XBI compared to Q2’22.

(1/4) – Logged third straight quarter of outperformance versus the $XBI. Finally have about made up for the Q2’21-Q4’21 underperformance. For now at least, holding on to a positive return for the year:  4%.

(3/3) Current Watchlist 
 
Own - $AEZS $PULM $ENVB 
Watchlist - $PTEIQ $DFFN $ARTL $INDP $APVO $SNOA

(2/3) Portfolio Updates (continued) 
 
$PULM - New holding. ~0.5% stake. Similar to AEZS, trades less than 0.5x. PUR3100 migraine treatment P1 data due in Q4.

(1/3) Portfolio Updates 
 
$NXGL - Booked profits with sales at $1.92 avg (5%-10% gain). Over my 2-month holding period, business had a decent earnings report, but not much else happened. Better opportunities have developed elsewhere.

Uneventful for my holdings this week. Current watchlist: 
 
Own - $AEZS $ENVB $NXGL 
Watchlist - $PULM $PTEIQ $APVO $HSDT $DRMA $GRI $SNOA

$ENVB ~17% of the share float is short currently. Split adjusted, the number of shares short is highest its been over the past year. With this short interest, not many additional shares to borrow, and a high borrow rate, this seems primed for a short squeeze.
$ENVB Borrow rate is >100% for anyone crazy enough to short.
$NXGL Nice to see open market buys continuing by insiders

(2/2) 
Own:  $AEZS $ENVB $SNOA  
Watchlist:  $PTEIQ $APVO $HSDT $SNOA

(1/2) Today's buys: 
 
$AEZS - Increased with buys in the $5.30-$5.40 range (averaged in at $5.17). 
$ENVB - New holding (average 6.82).
Buying into $ENVB. Will tweet updated list of holdings and watchlist later today.

(4/4) Current Holdings: 
 
~1.5%-2.0% $AEZS (significant buying this week) 
~0.5%-1.0% $NXGL 
 
Best of luck to those that continue to be long $CYCC.

(3/4) Now: 
 
-I’m out of both $ABIO and $CYCC 
-I’m up ~80% this quarter 
-I am at the highest point of my portfolio since Jul’21. 
 
These are things to be happy about - onward and upward! Pushing to reach all-time high from early 2021.
(2/4) Dollar-value-wise, it was my worst loss ever. As one would expect, the two names I bought when XBI was at an all-time high ( $ABIO, $CYCC) were a disaster.
(1/4) After nearly 18 months, I closed the books today on my investment in $CYCC. Average everything together and booked a 20%-25% loss across all shares bought/sold.
(2/2) $CYCC Sounds like this exposes the company to some risks. Additionally, it stops the company from using the ATM, which I am guessing helped the rally take place this week.

(1/2) Some thoughts on $CYCC 
 
Current dynamics are unique. Management has sold a couple million new shares through ATM recently. 10-Q/A filing from this week states that shares were erroneously sold through the ATM even though there was no active relevant shelf with the SEC.

(4/4) 
 
I Own - $CYCC $AEZS $NXGL 
Watchlist - $TSPT $HSDT $DRMA $APVO $SNOA

(3/4) Added: 
 
$AEZS – After being bearish on the name for nearly 10 years, even I can’t deny a name trading at <0.5x cash with a commercial-stage asset and an interesting preclinical therapeutics/vaccine pipeline that should continue to drive newsflow.

(2/4) Interesting week with newsflow. Changes: 
 
$CYCC – Trimmed position slightly in 1.60s down to 2.5% stake. Continues to be largest holding; look forward to further upside 
$NXGL – Trimmed off small number of shares to help create cash for new holding. Continue to like it.

(1/4) Current holdings: 
 
$CYCC – 2.5% 
$NXGL – 0.5%-1.0% 
$AEZS – 0.5%

Trimmed off a very small amount of $CYCC at $1.64 to increase my $NXGL position with a $1.86 buy. See lots of upside with both holdings. 
 
Own 
~3.0%-3.5% $CYCC 
~1.0% $NXGL 
 
Watchlist: 
$LUMO $APVO $TSPT $DRMA $SNOA
@Chiefbig23 There is more upside at $CYCC. I own 3.0%-3.5% of the business. Today has been a normal (and healthy) pullback. More upside to come!
$NXGL Bought more here today! Now up to ~1% position in the name.
$CYCC Great day today!

(2/2) Holdings 
~3.5% $CYCC 
~0.5%-1.0% $NXGL 
 
Watchlist $LUMO $APVO $TPST $DRMA $SNOA $HILS

(1/2) Started a new position in $NXGL at ~$1.76 average. 
 
Corporate deck from May’22 here ---> d1io3yog0oux5.cloudfront.ne... 
 
Will tweet some additional information on it when I have some extra time.

(2/2) $DRMA I couldn’t help myself with the opportunity to book a sizeable profit after two days, so sold at $0.69 average for a ~38% gain. I’ll take it! Will it continue to pop? It ver well might, but conservative approach guided best to just book the quick gain.

(1/2) $DRMA Another crazy day. 
 
On round #1, I booked a ~78% gain on 6/30 after holding for about a week. 
 
After the name declined back to my prior entry, I bought again at $0.50 on 7/5. Today (7/7), the stock popped again.

Today's Buys: 
 
$CYCC – I bought more here at $1.13. Why not? Now a 3.5% holder. 
 
$DRMA – I liked it at ~$0.50. It doubled so I booked the gain. Now, it’s back at ~$0.50, and I still like it just as I liked it previously! Bought ~$0.50-$0.51 to get back to being a 1.5% holder.

(3/3) $LABU Anyhow, I’m still a big biotech bull (so this is an odd time to sell given that), but I am over my skis continuing to own a 3x ETF when up a lot so sold at ~$8 to book the 50% gain. Thrilled with the result and happy to reinvest in specific names.
(2/3) I’m no expert at investing in 3x ETFs with all that leverage. I only make these plays when it is extremely obvious. I did it was $LABD in Feb’21 and now with $LABU in May’22.

(1/3) $LABU As I watched the ETF continue to rise (up ~100% in the past 3-4 weeks), I quickly started to get cold feet today. Don’t want to be greedy. Bulls make money, bears make money, and pigs get slaughtered.
(4/4) Going forward, I'll have my attention on my main holding $CYCC and will continue to ride the wave of the biotech recovery with $LABU (in the early innings).

(3/4) I’ve had realized gains/losses in 5 names this year. Unfortunately, $ABIO was the largest; reflecting, I feel this was predictable. I went bargain hunting in early '21 and XBI proceed to drop 60%-70% - believe I would have taken a big hit wherever I ended up being invested.
(2/4) It’s amazing how correlated things are these days. Even though the majority of what I own is microcaps, I still found myself very correlated with the $XBI.
(1/4) While it’s been yet another challenging year in biotech investing, happy to see my second quarter in a row beating the $XBI.

$CYCC My chips are on the table. Effectively I’m paying $1 for (a) $2 of cash plus (b) ongoing oncology trials guided by an experienced team including clinical experts that saw exceptional success with the ARQL buyout. 
 
Am I down currently? Yes. But, how can I not make a sizable bet here? As far as the bearish posts and the trolls, feel free to short at these levels and see where that gets you. Certainly would be nice for me to buy some more stock here and file my first 13G for a 5%+ stake; this is a type of opportunity that makes you consider it.

(4/4) So, current watchlist is as follows: 
 
Own: $CYCC $LABU 
Watching:  $APVO $LUMO $TPST $DRMA $SNOA $NXGL $HILS

(3/4) Regarding $CYCC, news was underwhelming (can post more on that this weekend). Lot of swing traders exited as the stock tanked. That said, nothing really scared me. Perhaps some timeline challenges, but no toxicity issues. Stock trades 0.4x-0.5x book value. I’m a buyer and thus bought heavily in $1.08-$1.11. Now own 3.0%-3.5% of the business.

(2/4) Regarding $DRMA, stock was up a ton on no news after I just bought a few days ago. That’s not something I need to think twice about. I booked a 78% gain on my 1.5%-2.0% stake with sales at ~$0.87 average after buying ~$0.49.

(1/4) Crazy day at the end of the quarter for my portfolio. 
 
$DRMA – Traded in $0.57-$1.04 range, up as much as 92% and closing up 20%. 
$CYCC – Traded in $1.01-$1.40 range, down as much as 32% and closing down 27%. 
 
So, how did I handle it?

Todays Trades: 
-Sold 1/3rd of $LABU for ~45% gain - holding rest for more upside 
-Increased position in $DRMA with buys 0.47-0.50 
 
Main Holdings: 
~2.0% of $CYCC 
~1.5%-2.0% of $DRMA
$LABU

(2/2) 
 
I Own:  $CYCC $DRMA $LABU  
Watchlist:  $LUMO $APVO $TPST $NXGL $SNOA $HILS

(1/2) Portfolio Update 
 
$DRMA Bought (own ~1%) 
$CYCC Reduced Slightly (own ~2% - largest holding) 
$LABU Long from $5.20
(3/3) $CYCC Here’s the near-term news expected over the next two months and a list of ongoing trials. Will post more later regarding some of the key ongoing trials.
(2/3) $CYCC Here’s the share structure and valuation information.

(1/3) I’m going to post information on $CYCC over time. I own a sizeable position as I don’t think it makes sense for a company with 2 intriguing clinical assets to trade at 0.4x-0.5x book value. I am spending more time on available information for the individual trials.

Updated watchlist with current valuation data. Only change from week ago is the CYCC/APVO change I tweeted on previously. 
 
I Own:  $CYCC $LABU 
Watchlist:  $LUMO $APVO $NXGL $TPST $DRMA $SNOA $HILS
Portfolio Updates:  Made the tough decision to book a quick profit on $APVO and increase my $CYCC to 2.0%-2.5% of the business.

Names on my radar 
 
I Own:  $APVO $CYCC $LABU 
Watchlist:  $LUMO $NXGL $DRMA $SNOA $HILS $TPST

Nearly doubled my $CYCC position today buying most of the shares that have traded. Stock trades at half or less of current cash balance, which is crazy. Still need to tweet out some more detailed update notes on it.
$APVO bears are even working weekends. Please sell me some shares if you are so bearish.

(3/3) Just me bidding in the $3.60-$3.80 range prevented $APVO from dropping even when the XBI was down big. I’ve currently got a ~0.5% position at ~$3.71. I’ll buy more if it pulls back (probably won’t). I’ll aim to tweet more on it when I find the time.
(2/3) In addition to $LABU (3x bull), I identified $APVO as my preferred name to own. While I wanted to take a 1.0%-1.5% stake, there was no one selling at the depressed levels this week!
(1/3) As mentioned, when I exited $ABIO, it was a “risk-on” trade – moving to opportunities that have been beaten down that have a lot of upside.

I’m going from owning $ABIO to “risk on". Back in early 2021, I had a very successful investment in $LABD. This week, I've positioned myself for a similar play - with $LABU. From my perspective, this is a unique opportunity not presented often.
I sold out of $ABIO. To current ABIO investors and the hedge fund that has accumulated 17% of the shares, I wish them the best.
$CYCC DEF 14A just out disproves the guess of ATM/offering shares causing the decline two weeks ago. Share count depicted here is the same as the share count in the 10-K.
(4/n) Here are some thoughts on $ABIO. I'll work up some notes on CYCC later.
(3/n) The length of without any good news for $ABIO and $CYCC has been crazy. Imagine who well the stocks will do once we finally get some good news! Here's my performance data.
Looking at the NASDAQ short report, pretty crazy that both $ABIO and $CYCC saw average volumes the first half of February that were lower than any time in the past year. Very quiet!
$OCUP Just received a payment of ~$0.08/share related to my 15-year $REXN CVR. Presumably related to the $91k referenced here near the bottom. I'll take it!

Topic #4 - Current Watchlist 
 
Own - $ABIO $CYCC  
Watchlist - $APVO $KTTA $LUMO $PRFX $SNOA $YTEN

Topic #3 - Cyclacel Pharmaceuticals ( $CYCC ) 
 
1. Two compelling assets in Fadraciclib (CDK9) and CYC140 (PLK1) 
2. Numerous readouts over the next 12 months. 
 
Why are we trading at a negative enterprise value? 
 
Continue to own a sizeable position.
(2/2) Here's the $ABIO summary.

(1/2) Topic #2 - Arca Biopharma ( $ABIO ) 
 
Stock trades near half the value of its current cash balance and has an upcoming AB201 readout in Q1. 
 
Trading at an Enterprise Value of negative $20-$25 million is just plain ridiculous.
(3/3) Here's longer-term stats over the past few years versus the $XBI.
(2/3) That brings the question of why are stocks that I felt were the best opportunities on my screen ( $ABIO and $CYCC ) in the second half of the first quarter performing this poorly?

(1/3) Topic #1 – Thoughts on 2021 Performance 
 
Closed out what was the third challenging quarter in a row. Even with a great first quarter, I finished the year underperforming the $XBI by about 4 percentage points.
As FYI to everyone, here's the update $LUMO short interest data - short numbers continue to decline.
$CYCC Taking a look at the 11/15/21 deck. Looks like we are due within the next few weeks a dosing of first patient for the CYC140 trial in solid tumors.

$LUMO There are 8.3 million shares outstanding, and there are only 60k shares short. That's less than 1% of outstanding. All of these posts about shorts are not very logical in my opinion. nasdaq.com/market-activity/...

$ABIO Nice insider buy. I'm curious to see if today's volume spikes are more insider buying. There was a 50k-share spike at 11:30am Eastern today and a 200k-share spike at 2:00pm-2:30pm Eastern spike. Let's see if we get another filing tomorrow.

(3/n) $ABIO 
All that said, I still think they can turn it around. To increase the share price of a stock (at Q3 end) trading at a $41 million market cap and a -$16 million enterprise value should be simple. I don’t see any reason to sell.

(2/n) $ABIO 
What management has done right: 
-No dilution over past few quarters 
 
Where management has failed: 
-Pushing forward with an asset (rNAPc2) while failing to get market buy-in on asset’s value 
-Constant rNAPc2 delays further damaging shareholder value 
-No progress with Gencaro 
-No strategic alternative to get market buy-in on capital deployment plans

(1/n) 
Looking back, $ABIO has been a frustrating name over the past year-plus. 
 
Market assessment of ABIO based on the data: 
-ABIO has created negative value over the past quarters (decline in enterprise value) 
-ABIO has failed to prove there is any value to its clinical assets.
$ABIO Interesting - looks like they are in the early stages of ramping up for the Gencaro Phase 3. Planning to read release and 10-Q closer tonight.

Interesting week for $ABIO. Provided a positive DSMC interim analysis based on 75% of the projected upcoming data. Unfortunately, it also came with another data delay (to Q1). Over a 24-hour period, it traded ~14 million shares (about the amount of total shares outstanding). Stock sold off pretty quickly in after hours, went flat by midday today, and then rallied a bit in the afternoon to close up 5%. I expect it to trade at elevated volumes over the next week (though probably sees volume dry up gradually as the week progresses. Big move will likely require a Gencaro update or the rNAPc2 readout, though there is always the potential for a surprise!
Highest volume for $ABIO in two months and highest close for $CYCC in about a month. Actually having a decent quarter so far. Excited for further upside!
(5/5) $ABIO data finally due this quarter. Trading $13 million under current estimated cash on the balance sheet.
(4/5) $CYCC ramping up trial activity with Fadra and CYC140 – shaping up for an exciting 2022.

(3/5) 
Own:  $ABIO $CYCC 
Watchlist:  $PMCB $LUMO $INDP $BNTC $YTEN $PRFX
(2/5) Held $ABIO and $CYCC for the duration of the quarter. Did not make any changes. Amazing how correlated these names were to the XBI even though they are microcaps.

(1/5) Another lackluster quarter for me. Hard to believe, but 3 straight quarters of losses for the $XBI (though loss in Q2 was very small). 
 
Year-to-date: 
 
Portfolio:  +6% 
XBI:  -10%

Here’s where I’m at currently: 
 
I own $ABIO $CYCC 
Watchlist $BNTC $INDP $LUMO $RVPH $YTEN 
 
Continue to see a lot of opportunity with $ABIO $CYCC.

Today's 39k shares traded with $ABIO was the lowest number of shares since May 27, 2020 (the day before the big pop on 83 million shares). We've been waiting for material news for what seems like forever and volume has now dried up to nearly nothing. And we continue to wait for news...

Absolutely not surprising from $NURO. While the business is nearly breakeven, management ramping up ATM usage. 
 
Through the ATM, $NURO increased share count by 30% over 2 months (between April 21 and June 24). 
 
I'll stay away for now, letting them finish their dilution/selling.

(2/3) I don’t feel like I missed a ton of opportunities I wanted to jump on, but there certainly were a couple I had to ignore – opportunity cost! Funny thing is that I still like $ABIO and $CYCC as holdings. All I can do is just shrug and move to the next quarter.

(1/3) Worst quarter for me since beginning of pandemic. Came into quarter with $ABIO and $CYCC as my main holdings. Left the quarter with $ABIO and $CYCC as my main holdings. Don’t think I’ve been through a more boring quarter with literally nothing happening with what I owned.

Me thinking about reviewing my Q2 performance numbers after $CYCC has been dragging on my performance. $ABIO not helping either.

Ready for a new quarter!
$ABIO $CYCC Looks like management missed the memo about finally giving us some news this morning. Back to the waiting game...

Going to my regular dentist appointment in the morning. Last time I went, $XBIO popped 400%+ on news as I was headed to my appointment. $ABIO or $CYCC are welcome to wake up from their respective slumbers and do that as well in the morning.
$ABIO $CYCC At the risk of seeming a bit impatient, I'm going to take the new month as an opportunity to drop this right here in these two streams....

Continues to be a pretty quiet quarter for my portfolio. Currently +0% vs. -7% for the $XBI. 
 
Main holdings continue to be $CYCC and $ABIO 
 
Here are my thoughts: 
 
Also Buyable: $NURO $PRFX $SNOA 
Watchlist: $BNTC $YTEN

(2/2) Some interesting names such as Point72 – nearly 50% institutional ownership for $CYCC. 
 
This is the largest holding for me now given strong performance in Q2 relative to the biotech market overall.

(1/2)  
 
(data downloaded from @whalewisdom – added ownership calculation) 
 
An impressive list of institutions reporting $CYCC ownership on 13-Fs for the first time (see gold highlights). 
 
A couple of these known from prior 13Gs, but most is new info.
$ABIO Someone pointed out to me that I was missing an open market insider buy by the Chairman in December. Update attached. He's actually in for nearly $200k so far.
Nice to see another open market insider buy from the $ABIO Chairman. He's put $150k into buying stock on the open market over the past couple of quarters.

$ABIO A number of people tried to claim that the company was restarting use of the ATM. Well, that's been proved wrong. Share count in 10-Q as of yesterday is consistent with share count from 10-K - 14,410,143 shares.

There seems to be a general belief out there that the stock market constantly goes up and automatically prints money for everyone; unfortunately, that's not how it works. For me, the combination of $ABIO $CYCC are down about 11% this quarter compared to a 9% decline for the $XBI. That's fine. No problem. Contrary to popular belief, stocks do not always go up. After a solid Q1 (up 30%-40% vs. a 3% decline in the XBI), I'm well aware that I wont make money every day. Stocks go up, stocks go down. Good investors will have more ups than downs. I know what I own. I like what I own. I'm comfortable with / confident in ABIO and CYCC. Not much else to say and just a matter of patience.

(4/n) $NURO – I’ve previously championed this name given Medicare Advantage tailwinds, attractive gross margin, and turning the corner to profitability. Probably fairly valued after popping more than 100% since I bought in last year, but I think fine to buy something like this with a ton of upside if you don’t like holding cash.

(3/n) $SNOA – I’ve previously had challenges with the name. Irrespective of that, they’ve rightsized their cost structures since, EV is <$5 million, and they’ve just turned EBITDA positive. In a space where businesses trade at multiples of revenue, net of cash, the stock currently trades <0.5x revenue. Additionally, investor Montreux clearly pretty involved and played matchmaker in recent deal (Crown Labs).

(2/n) $ABIO – This remains most undervalued name in the market. 
 
-Trades at ~0.8x book value / cash as of today 
-Minimal cash burn 
-COVID treatment readout in Q2’21 
-P3-ready asset in GENCARO (SPA in place with FDA) 
-Chance of a surprise strategic alternative 
 
I own ~1%.

(1/n) After going to mostly cash a couple weeks ago due to a materially overvalued nanocap bio space, I’ve been doing a fair amount of research this weekend on opportunities in the space. 
 
With the ~15% drop in the $XBI, where does my opinion sit currently? 
 
Is the nanocap bio space still materially overvalued? I don’t think so. A lot of the materially overvalued names have seen significant declines. 
 
Is the nanocap bio space still simply overvalued (but not materially so)? Yes, I would say so. 
 
That said, I do think one can find investment opportunities in an overvalued market 
 
For people that don’t like holding cash, let me share a sample of some names I like.
